race.name: The Divide
race.tagline: Manistee National Forest gravel and two-track through northern Michigan.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Michigan countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Michigan event. Rolling terrain with moderate access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: The Divide is a local event in Michiganâ€”rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Michigan countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Michigan gravel race. Worth it for Michigan/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Michiganâ€”yes, it's good value. If you're travelingâ€”skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Michigan races: Barry-Roubaix, Iceman Cometh.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Manton has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Manton has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Michigan rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Registration opens at 9:00 AM at Railroad Park in downtown Manton, with starts between 9:00-2:00 PM depending on the year. Christina Vipond praised organizers Jeff and Don: 'volunteers were stationed throughout the course to make sure racers stayed on course.' However, no parking, lodging, or packet pickup details are documented anywhere.

length.explanation: The 50-mile distance delivers what Jared Dunham called 'probably the most memorable 50 mile race course I've done so far... very hilly with some sand thrown in.' Three distance options (19/34/50 miles) mean beginners get their shorter route while the full distance provides substantial challenge without epic 100+ mile suffering. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: Lachlan Morton ran Vittoria Terreno Dry 38mm tires at Unbound, while Alex Howes opted for the same setup without aerobars, noting 'he had it a lot harder than the guys who had mounted extensions.' The sandy two-track through Gilbert Corners keeps riders guessing about equipment choices, though skill and high-volume tires make the course rideable at speed. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Matthew Lee gained strategic advantage in 2009 by 'beginning his climb up Richmond Peak at 5am whereas the others did not start until 5:45am.' All routes are described as 'very hilly' with El Diablo on E. 35 Rd. being 'both steep and long.' The 2500 feet over 50 miles creates consistent climbing without massive single ascents. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Weather volatility defines the divide experience. In 2009, 'quarter-inch sized hail was beginning to be a near-daily occurrence for race leaders,' while other years saw riders awakening to 'frost covered bikes. Brrr!' The July timing puts riders into peak summer heat, though recent races moved start times earlier to avoid the worst temperatures. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Weather-related challenges puts it: "Due to the weather, racers are likely wearing through their drivetrains much faster than previous years, which will likely cause many of them to have to pre-maturely replace them once they get into Co..."

altitude.explanation: Manton, Michigan sits firmly in the Midwest flatlands with no meaningful elevation above sea level. The hills are real, but you're not getting any altitude training benefits or respiratory challenges here. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds â€” no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Giorgio Dalla Costa described his divide experience as accepting 'Art expressing herself spontaneously, without any compromise, traveling, dreaming, feeling free.' The course through Manistee National Forest includes the named Redneck Roughneck downhill and Amish Sawmill area, creating memorable character beyond typical gravel racing.

prestige.explanation: Started in 2015 as a fundraiser for Manton Public School's cross country and track teams, The Divide remains a regional Michigan Gravel Race Series event. Elite riders like Matthew Lee and Lael Wilcox race the Tour Divide, not this small-town Michigan fundraiser. No pro field, prize purse, or notable winners documented.

race_quality.explanation: Three distance options and thoughtful course design with named features like El Diablo and Gilbert Corners show someone cares. Michael Hodges noted courses are 'marked to perfection, aid stations are well stocked' with 'that good ol' races with the old school ultra vibe.' The Outer Loop alternates direction annually, which most organizers wouldn't bother with.

experience.explanation: The mix of forest roads and sandy two-track through Amish territory creates memorable character. Bethany described divide terrain where 'the road was a little boggy but it was worth it, the views were some of the best of the entire Divide.' However, starting from a small Michigan railroad park limits the overall experience compared to destination events.

community.explanation: Being part of the Michigan Gravel Race Series means there's a regional scene that shows up consistently. Flint and Scarlet Zeigler emphasized how divide experiences create lasting bonds: 'heartfelt bridges are built again' through shared challenges. The fundraiser nature and team discounts suggest they're trying to build something beyond just racing.

field_depth.explanation: Hunter Post won his age group with 4th overall, while Terry Ritter took 1st in 50+ class, indicating thin competitive depth across categories. Michael Hodges finished 13th 'just 1:40 behind 9th place' in a different divide race, suggesting modest field sizes where top-10 finishes are achievable for recreational racers. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Weather-related challenges puts it: "Due to the weather, racers are likely wearing through their drivetrains much faster than previous years, which will likely cause many of them to have to pre-maturely replace them once they get into Co..."

value.explanation: Three distance options, team discounts, and a thoughtfully designed course through national forest territory without premium destination pricing. Alexandera Houchin's singlespeed record attempt shows divide racing rewards preparation over expensive equipment. The 50-mile option delivers real mileage for whatever they're charging while supporting local school athletics.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Manton, Michigan keeps lodging and food costs reasonable compared to tourist destinations. Equipment requirements stay modest - riders have suggested 'tires in the mid 32-38cc and up' without exotic gear needs. Entry fees aren't documented, but the fundraiser nature and regional scope likely keep costs accessible for Michigan riders. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: The Divide - 50mi (Gravel Race) 2023
videos.description:
ðŸ‘‰ Hey! SUBSCRIBE for free WATTS ðŸ‘‰ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsr-SU_SAqjrzmu4kXIRfUQ?sub_confirmation=1

* At 17:50 I realized I lost my bottle that had ALL of my nutrition and electrolytes for the entire race!
* At 21:40 I had to remove my rear broken GoPro that was hanging on by one zip tie.

The number one goal of this race was to stay safe. This race was 2 weeks prior to a planned 7 day Colorado bike packing trip, so crashing and injuries were not an option. I had to play this safe and conservative. Which resulted in me basically doing a solo TT after the first 20 minutes. 

This race was a bit a mess for me. After realizing I lost all my nutrition, but didn't know exactly when or where,  I was scrambling on how to resolve this. First I thought maybe I'll just try to finish the race without any fuel, ugh. Then, I thought surely my competition would have extra and willing to share.... they did not. Finally, at some point I remembered something about Aid Stations that was briefed at the start when I wasn't paying attention. So the goal was to find some of those and rely on whatever they had.   

I found the first aid station at 42:05 and their was a bit of confusion as all they said they had was Coke, water and pickles, but no gels or fuel. I heard one of the guys call out Gatorade and realized they at least had that, so filled my bottle and chugged some Coke.  I stopped at 52:01 and topped off my bottle and again at 1:35:50. At 1:27:01 I nailed my my first ever drink hand-up from a volunteer handing out Gatorade.  Even though my nutrition plan was gone and the aid station mix was upsetting my stomach, I stayed positive and kept steady. I was able to pick off quite a few riders later in the race which was encouraging and placed 19th overall, my best gravel race finish to date.

The Divide is a gravel road bike race held in Manton, MI. The Divide is a part of the Michigan Gravel Race Series and there are three distances to choose from; 19, 34, & 50 miles.   All three routes are very hilly (4K+ elevation gain) and include a mixture of gravel, seasonal, and forest roads some of which have some very deep sandy spots, plenty that require forced hike-a-bike.

tags: extreme xc battle in the gravel
videos.curation_reason: Full 50-mile race experience with highest view count and detailed course challenges including nutrition loss and technical issues.

videos.title: The Divide - 50mi (Gravel Race) 2024
videos.description:
ðŸ‘‰ Hey! SUBSCRIBE for free WATTS ðŸ‘‰ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsr-SU_SAqjrzmu4kXIRfUQ?sub_confirmation=1

The Divide is a gravel road race held in Manton, MI. The Divide is a part of the Michigan Gravel Race Series and there were three distances to choose from; 19, 34, & 50 miles.  I raced the 50 mile but all routes are hilly (50 mi has 4K+ elevation gain) and include a mixture of gravel, seasonal, and forest roads. There were also some very deep sandy spots that require forced hike-a-bike. The 50 mile was interesting as it was an out, 2 loops, then a back. The "out" and "back" were the really sandy sections but the "loops" were hilly but good gravel.

It's been a tough go of training over the past few weeks as I've had to travel a lot for work, work long hours and had many nights of poor sleep. Couple that with this week being the end of my "recovery week", left my legs feeling flat and heavy. I didn't have high expectations but hoped my previous months of training would carry me through.

Early on a breakaway of 2 went off the front never to be seen again with the eventual winner of the race. Then, there was a split between the 34 and 50 milers that juggled the group. Apparently a last minute change was all groups and all distances going off in one mass group start. After the split a lead group formed until we hit the deep sand sections where we split up. We all regrouped once, but then the group shattered again once we hit more deep sand. From there were only singles and small groups remaining. I didn't have the legs on the day to go with the few ahead, so I settled into a group of 3 (7th - 9th place). Early on we passed a rider and became 6th - 8th place but never saw anyone from our race and basically just settled into a sustainable pace.

On the way back after the loops into the sandy sections I lost my front wheel in some deep sand and toppled over. The topple over was slow and soft, but the guy running into me from behind was not. Our bikes got tangled and scratched up, but were ridable. I was able to quickly get going and eventually dropped the 2 guys I was riding with all race. Shorty after I caught 5th place and thought we could work together to the finish. Unfortunately he crashed and never caught up to me to work together.  Coming out of the sand I had a 40 second gap, but noticed the 3 I had dropped were all together. With 20+ minutes remaining in the race, I knew I wouldn't be able to hold them off if they worked together. So I slow pedaled and waited for them to catch up becoming a group of 4 (5th - 8th place).

The 4 of us stayed together until about the last mile where the wheel I was following got gapped on the last big hill. I gambled and thought one of the guys would close it, but they never did and 5th place got away. Ugh, I played that wrong. So, now I was sprinting for 6th place amongst the 3 of us and just waited to make my move. I was able secure 6th place , just 6 seconds behind 5th place and 20 seconds behind 4th place whom we never saw. 

ðŸ‘‰ Hey! SUBSCRIBE for free WATTS ðŸ‘‰ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsr-SU_SAqjrzmu4kXIRfUQ?sub_confirmation=1
tags: extreme xc battle in the gravel
videos.curation_reason: Recent full-distance race coverage with specific details about 4K+ elevation gain and forced hike-a-bike sections through deep sand.

videos.title: The Divide 34 Mile Gravel Race - 2023 - Odd Year Course
videos.description:
The Divide Gravel Race in Manton, Michigan is part of the Michigan Gravel Race Series. There are 19, 34 and 50 mile distances. The 34 and 50 mile courses rotate direction each year. Lots of climbing, two track and gnarly sand. This is definitely the most difficult race in the MGRS, but so worth the challenge. Highly recommend if you haven't been to it!

No notable results for me, as I started too far back from the front group thinking I could catch up right away, but that wasn't the case. I thought for sure they'd settle and would be able to catch them, but I was dead wrong. Still had a great race with good group of riders.

https://hardracingevents.com/events/the-divide/
https://www.michigangravelraceseries.com/
videos.curation_reason: Complete race experience with valuable course description highlighting it as the most difficult race in the Michigan Gravel Race Series.
